conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on the suitcase and use the given information to find the values of \(\mu\) and \(\theta\).
The image shows a suitcase which can be either pushed or pulled on the ground.
The total mass of the suitcase is 15 kg, and the gravitational acceleration is 10 m/s².
The resistance of the suitcase to the ground is proportional to the supporting force of the ground, the ratio is \(\mu\).
A passenger pulls the suitcase with an oblique upward pull to do uniform movement on the horizontal ground.
The minimum value of the pull is 90 N, and the angle between the pull and the horizontal direction is \(\theta\).
The sine of 37° is given as 0.6.

premise: Gravitational force \(G = mg\), where \(m = 15\) kg and \(g = 10\) m/s².
conclusion: The gravitational force acting on the suitcase is \(G = 150\) N.
The normal force is the supporting force exerted by the ground on the suitcase.
The passenger pulls the suitcase with a force \(F = 90\) N at an angle \(\theta\) above the horizontal.
The frictional force is proportional to the normal force, given by \(f = \mu N\).

premise: The pulling force \(F\) can be resolved into two components.
conclusion: Horizontal component: \(F_x = F \cos \theta\), Vertical component: \(F_y = F \sin \theta\).

premise: The suitcase is in uniform motion, so the net force in the vertical direction is zero.
The suitcase is in uniform motion, so the net force in the horizontal direction is zero.
Substitute \(N = 150 - 90 \sin \theta\) into the horizontal force equation.
